chat.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Now live for all: Substack Notes - On Substack - https://on.substack.com/p/notes

Now live for all: Substack Notes - On Substack

Substack has announced the launch of Notes, a new feature offering a space for short-form posts and idea-sharing among writers and readers. Unlike inbox posts, Notes will not be sent to subscribers via email. The feature is designed to assist writers in growing their audiences and revenue. Notes can include images, rich text, links and mentions, and lives in the Notes tab beside Inbox at substack.com and in Substack mobile apps. The Substack team plans to evolve the feature based on user feedback.

- Notes is a new feature on Substack for short-form posts
- It will not be sent to subscribers, and instead will help posts find a valuable audience of writers and readers in the Substack ecosystem
- Users can share links, images, comments, and snippets from Substack posts on Notes
- It is a lightweight and fun feature, designed to help writers grow their audience and revenue
- Notes can be accessed via the Notes tab on substack.com and in Substack's mobile apps
- It is a long-term project and is expected to evolve rapidly in response to user feedback
- The feature can become a powerful driver of subscriptions, as historically sharing posts has been one of the major ways that writers find growth on Substack
- Notes can include up to 6 photos or GIFs, and users can include images in both notes and replies
- The Home tab shows notes from writers users subscribe to or writers they recommend, while the Subscribed tab shows notes and activity from writers users have subscribed to directly
- The Substack team plans to evolve the feature based on user feedback and encourage users to offer their ideas

‚ö†Ô∏è Twitter introduces 10,000-character-long tweets for Blue subscribers | TechCrunch - https://techcrunch.com/2023/04/13/twitter-introduces-10000-character-long-tweets-for-blue-subscribers/?guccounter=1

Twitter introduces 10,000-character-long tweets for Blue subscribers | TechCrunch

Twitter has introduced a feature for Blue subscribers to post 10,000-character-long tweets, while supporting bold and italic text formatting. The push for long-form writing comes as Elon Musk rolls out creator monetisation tools. Tesla's CEO recently allowed creators to apply for monetisation and offer subscriptions to users, stating that Twitter would give all the proceeds to its creators for the next 12 months. However, it is unclear why Musk said Google charged 30% tax on subscriptions, as its terms stated it charged only 15%.

- Twitter's Blue subscribers can now post tweets up to 10,000 characters long and use bold and italic text formatting.
- Elon Musk has rolled out Twitter's new feature that allows creators to apply for monetization and receive subscriptions to users.
- Twitter will give all revenue collected to creators for the first 12 months after paying a 30% cut to Apple or Google's tax.
- The social media company's monetization tools are only available for US users and available to creators who have at least 18 years of age, 10,000 active followers, and tweeted 25 times in the last 30 days.
- Long-form writing is not new to Twitter, but Musk's new feature is an extension of the existing Super Follows program that he has rebranded.
- A battle with competitor Substack, due to the rollout of its Twitter-like feed called Notes, has led to Twitter blocking links to Substack.
- In February, Twitter promised an ad revenue-sharing feature for Blue subscribers, but the feature has not appeared anywhere yet.
‚ö†Ô∏è Amazon launches CodeWhisperer, a GitHub Copilot-like AI pair programming tool | TechCrunch - https://techcrunch.com/2022/06/23/amazon-launches-codewhisperer-its-ai-pair-programming-tool/

Amazon launches CodeWhisperer, a GitHub Copilot-like AI pair programming tool | TechCrunch

Amazon announced CodeWhisperer, an AI pair programming tool that autocompletes functions based on comments or keystrokes. The tool is currently available for preview as part of the AWS IDE Toolkit and can be used in various IDEs, including IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm, and AWS Cloud 9. It supports Java, JavaScript, and Python and is trained on billions of lines of code from public sources and Amazon's own codebase. Users can also test the system for any security issues, and it continually highlights its sources, assuring query ability.

- Amazon launched CodeWhisperer, an AI pair programming tool similar to GitHub's Copilot.
- It can autocomplete functions based on comments or keystrokes from the developer using Java, JavaScript, or Python.
- The system was trained on billions of lines of code, publicly available open-source code, Amazon's own codebase, and publicly available documentation and codes.
- CodeWhisperer is available for preview as part of the AWS IDE Toolkit, supporting various Integrated Development Environments.
- The system highlights sources and scans the user's codes for potential security issues.
- It scans generated and changed code to find possible vulnerabilities.
- The tool does things differently from Copilot, highlighting existing code similarities and its sources.
- CodeWhisperer teams worked hard to eliminate biased codes and added filters to automatically remove biased codes.
- Developers can test the system and see how it works as it continues to generate new code snippets.

XUL Layout is gone | Words

The XUL layout has been removed from the Firefox codebase after a nine-year effort, resulting in the use of web technology for all Firefox UI. A lack of maintenance, proprietary technology, and conflicting CSS rules are among the reasons why it was removed. The removal is viewed as a step forward for Firefox, as it now uses the same technology as most websites.
- XUL layout removed from Firefox codebase using web technology for all Firefox UI
- Bad interactions with regular box model
- XUL lacked proper support for basic CSS features, like proper absolute positioning
- Firefox desktop front-end used regular website CSS, eliminating need for XUL layout
- XUL was proprietary, poorly documented and not actively maintained
- Switch to web technology makes Firefox more compatible with most websites
- Removal viewed as a step forward for Firefox

GitHub Accelerator: our first cohort and what's next | The GitHub Blog

GitHub has announced the first cohort of its GitHub Accelerator program, which will support open source maintainers to work on their projects, providing an initial sponsorship of $20,000 and guidance from open-source leaders. Over 1,000 applications were received, with the 20 selected projects spanning industries, software stack, project maturity, and funding goals.

* GitHub Accelerator announces the first cohort of 20 projects with 32 participants from around the world, offering them sponsorship and guidance to work on their open-source projects.
* GitHub received over 1,000 applications and selected the projects based on their diversity, the software stack, project maturity, funding goals, and industries.
* The program aims to provide support to the maintainers and projects wanting to make a full-time career in open source by building durable streams of funding for their work.
* During the 10-week program, the group will participate in weekly sessions with open source thought leaders and focus on building and maintaining their projects.
* Topics covered will include open-source licensing and governance, setting funding goals, working with companies, getting sponsorships, prioritizing issues, onboarding new contributors, securing your project, managing tough conversations, building partnerships, keeping communities safe, fundraising skills, and more.
* At the end of the program, GitHub will share an update on what they learned and what's next for these projects.
* GitHub also announced that GitHub Sponsors is now available for organization-funded sponsorships, making it easier for organizations to sponsor open-source projects.

‚ÄòOveremployed‚Äô Hustlers Exploit ChatGPT To Take On Even More Full-Time Jobs

https://www.vice.com/en/article/v7begx/overem...

‚ÄòOveremployed‚Äô Hustlers Exploit ChatGPT To Take On Even More Full-Time Jobs

AI chatbot ChatGPT, developed by research lab OpenAI, has been used by savvy ‚Äúoveremployed‚Äù workers to automate tasks more efficiently and enable them to take on multiple roles at once. The technology has been used for tasks from transcribing Zoom meetings to typing up business plans, and some workers have cited it as the reason they got their job. The trend has raised concerns over the future of automation and the potential loss of jobs, with one expert comparing the technology to the modern loom in the textile industry.

- Artificial intelligence chatbot ChatGPT has been used by ‚Äúoveremployed‚Äù workers to ease the burden of taking on multiple jobs at once.
- ChatGPT has been used for a variety of tasks, from creating presentations to crafting cover letters and blog posts.
- Workers have cited the technology as the reason they are able to work multiple jobs or complete their roles more efficiently than before.
- The technology has raised concerns over the future of automation and the potential loss of jobs.
- The trend has led to an "arms race" among workers to determine how much of the workday can be automated by AI tools.
- While workers maintain that their jobs require a certain level of expertise or input, some worry that the technology could lead to automation of their roles.
- Others see the potential benefits of ChatGPT as an ‚Äúassistant‚Äù, handling the more menial aspects of their job to allow them more freedom to focus on higher-level tasks.

–ù–æ–≤—ã–π —Å–±–æ—Ä—â–∏–∫ Java –ø—Ä–æ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤ Bld https://foojay.io/today/introducing-bld-a-new...

bld is designed with the following principles in mind:


tasks don‚Äôt happen without you telling them to happen

no auto-magical behavior, task behavior is explicit and API-defined

managing libs yourself is fine, having that automated also, or mix and match

build logic is written in Java, with all the advantages of Java

standard collection of Java-centric tasks for common operations

bld is part of RIFE2, if you have the RIFE2 jar, you have the build system

Introducing Bld: A New Pure Java Build System

Bld is a new pure Java build system that enables developers to write build logic in Java. It was created to reduce cognitive load, eliminate auto-magical behavior and make the build logic explicit and API-defined. Bld is part of RIFE2 and uses Java 17. It supports auto-completion, javadoc documentation, and you can split your build logic into multiple files and classes.

- Bld is a new pure Java build system
- It enables developers to write build logic in Java
- Bld is designed to reduce cognitive load, eliminate auto-magical behavior, and make build logic explicit and API-defined
- Bld uses Java 17 and supports auto-completion and javadoc documentation
- Developers can split their build logic into multiple files and classes
- Bld is part of RIFE2 and supports auto-download of library dependencies
- Bld project files are powered by Java and RIFE2, providing extensive possibilities
- You can learn more on the RIFE2 bld wiki or by reaching out to developers on Discord or Mastodon.

–£–ø–æ–º–∏–Ω–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –æ DAN (Do Anything Now) –ø—Ä–æ–º–ø—Ç–∞—Ö, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã—Ö —É–∂–µ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–Ω–æ —Å –¥–µ—Å—è—Ç–æ–∫

The Hacking of ChatGPT Is Just Getting Started | WIRED

A report has suggested that the jailbreaking of AI models, such as OpenAI's GPT and Microsoft Bing‚Äôs chatbot, is becoming more creative and harder to detect, with ‚Äúlateral thinking‚Äù methods being used. While most tech companies claim to be striving to counteract such attacks through red-teaming and other defensive strategies, some researchers fear that the pace of change of AI is outstripping its security. Prompt injection attacks, in which attackers plant malicious code that the text generators including GPT-4 pick up and follow, are also seen as a concern.

- As AI models increase in power and popularity, they become a target to malicious attackers
- Jailbreaking and prompt injections aim to override or actively sabotage an AI model
- Red-teaming is often used to test vulnerabilities before release, but prompts are much harder to monitor
- Techniques, including reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF), are being developed to counteract the threat
- The rate of AI development, however, looks set to make it difficult to stay ahead of malicious actors
